thread.title_full: Karen Ristevski's brother-in-law 'has connections' to property in police search area - 9news.com.au

author: Nine.Com.Au Staff
title: Karen Ristevski's brother-in-law 'has connections' to property in police search area - 9news.com.au
text:
Karen Ristevski's brother-in-law 'has connections' to property in police search area By nine.com.au staff 
Karen Ristevski's brother-in-law allegedly has connections to a property close to where items were found in the search for the Melbourne mother's body, according to reports. 
The investigations into the 47-year-old's death have continued after police confirmed on Monday her remains had been found in bushland at Mount Macedon, Victoria. 
Overnight, it emerged Ms Ristevski's brother-in-law, Vasko, owned a racehorse which was trained at a stud on the same road authorities included in their search, the Herald Sun reports. 
Mr Ristevski is the brother of Borce, Ms Ristevski's husband, and partly-owned the horse Faltastic, the newspaper claims. 
The stud is on Blackhill Road, an area that frames the bushland where police searched in December. Police say they found “evidence” at the site but have not revealed what they found. 
News of the property connection comes as police confirm they were called last year to investigate the area on the tip offs of locals. 
A Mount Macedon resident, who gave his name only as Dean, told police he witnessed two men matching the description of the brothers bogged in a white truck on Salisbury Road in the days after her disappearance. 
The spot is metres from where Ms Ristevski's remains were found. 
Dean said he came forward after spending "sleepless nights" wondering if what he saw was connected to the missing Ms Ristevski. 
It was also revealed this morning police fitted a tracking device to a car used by Borce in the months after Ms Ristevski disappeared but it was either removed or fell off, The Age reports. 
It is not unusual for tracking devices to be fitted to the vehicles of suspects, sources close to the investigation told the newspaper. 
Police also believe Mr Ristevski had been warned against speaking on phones and could have been given information about investigative techniques homicide detectives use. 
Mr Ristevski visited the office of leading criminal lawyer Rob Stary on Wednesday. Mr Stary has since claimed police consider Mr Ristevski the "number one suspect" in the murder investigation, but maintains his client’s innocence. Mr Ristevski was interviewed by police shortly after his wife’s disappearance and released. 
Ms Ristevski's body was found on Monday wedged between two logs in bushland. She had been missing since June 29 last year. © Nine Digital Pty Ltd 2017 TRENDING VIDEO 'This is not Trump's America!': Passenger accused of racism kicked off flight A US man who was accused of taunting a Pakistani couple while they were boarding a flight has found himself booted from the plane – to the cheers of fellow passengers.
